I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
India for the Rajasthan Secondary Towns Development Sector Project. 
 
2.  The project will support the Government of Rajasthan (GOR) in expanding access to 
improved water supply services for about 570,000 people, and improved sanitation services for 
about 720,000 people in at least 14 secondary towns1 by drawing on experiences and lessons 
from three earlier projects funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Rajasthan.2 The 
project will finance climate-resilient and inclusive water supply and sanitation (WSS) infrastructure 
in Rajasthan’s secondary towns, including heritage towns; empower local governments and 
strengthen  their  institutional  capacity;  and  deepen  sector  reforms  to  ensure  improved  and 
sustainable service delivery in line with GOR’s investment program. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  State demographics and economy. Rajasthan is the largest state in India; it has 10% of 
the country’s land area, 5% of its population, and only about 1% of its surface water resources. 
About 17 million people (25% of Rajasthan’s population) live in 193 urban centers. Rajasthan has 
done more to reduce poverty than any of India’s other low-income states particularly between 
2005 and 2012—the population below poverty line (BPL) declined from 38% in 1994, to 34% in 
2005, and further to 15% in 2012.3 Cities are places of opportunity in Rajasthan: the urban poverty 
rate averages 11% compared with 16% in rural areas.4 Rajasthan’s Urban Development Policy 
(2017) emphasizes public service improvement in urban areas as a key contributing factor to 
strive for growth and poverty reduction. Important national and state government initiatives seek 
to stimulate industrial development and create jobs for migrants and local people, including 
numerous industrial parks throughout the state developed by GOR. In addition, 39% of the Delhi–
Mumbai Industrial Corridor is situated in Rajasthan. Tourism is also a major economic driver, with 
50 million tourists (including 1.8 million foreign tourists) in 2018, double the figure in 2010. 5 
However, the state’s economic development is constrained by water availability, and GOR has 
several plans to increase water supply for industrial and domestic consumption. 
 
4.  Urbanization  challenges.  Urbanization  in  India  has  outpaced  the  development  of 
infrastructure to meet basic needs and the capacity of institutions to deliver high-quality and 
sustainable services in cities, and large gaps remain to be filled to ensure high-quality urban WSS 
services for all, including the poor and vulnerable. The 74th amendment to India’s Constitution 
(enacted  in  1992)  devolved  service  delivery  to  local  governments,  while  multiple  national

Substantial resources and support are still required to empower local governments and improve

5.  Sector overview. GOR has a sector development plan for urban WSS that includes 
investment and sustainability road maps, with a greater focus on secondary towns than previous 
plans. 7 GOR has prepared detailed project reports for over 50 secondary towns in line with the 
plan. In the state’s secondary towns, which have not yet received ADB support, water supply 
coverage  can  be  relatively  high—but  water  quality  is  poor,  and  services  are  intermittent, 
unreliable,  and  inefficient.  High  transmission  and  distribution  system  losses  are  a  major 
contributor to the poor service quality. In the project towns, households receive an average of 1.5 
hours of water per day; there are inequities in distribution, and a high incidence of waterborne 
diseases, while the coping costs—to purchase, pump, and treat water from alternative sources— 
are also high. Most connections are unmetered. Women are primarily responsible for collecting, 
transporting, using, and managing water, but have almost no involvement in decision-making in 
the sector. Low levels of fecal sludge collection, treatment, and safe disposal have led to an 
unsanitary environment with negative impacts on health and economic growth. Despite the 
progress in sector reforms, most urban local bodies (ULBs) have inadequate technical staff and 
own-source revenues to manage citywide WSS services, and have limited experience in (i) all 
functions of WSS operations, (ii) smart water features to be included in the project, and (iii) 
management and monitoring of operation and maintenance (O&M) contractors. 
 
6.  Assistance of ADB and other development partners. Since 2000, the state has 
successfully  implemented  two  multisector  urban  investment  projects  supported  by  ADB, 
benefitting more than 7 million people in 21 class 18 and class 2 cities (footnote1), with improved 
quality of life, increased access to economic opportunities, and considerable benefits for the 
poor.9 The third project, Rajasthan Urban Sector Development Program, is ongoing and supports 
investments in six class 1 cities as well as sector reforms (footnote 2). With support from ADB in 
the form of physical investments, technical assistance, and policy-based lending, GOR has 
developed the enabling environment to expand and increase access to and the quality of WSS 
services throughout the state, and more efficiently use scarce water resources. Transformative 
reforms undertaken under the program include (i) establishment of the Rajasthan Urban Drinking 
Water, Sewerage and Infrastructure Corporation Limited (RUDSICO), a corporatized entity, to 
expand urban investments and implement urban reform agendas; (ii) adoption of a sewage and 
wastewater policy, the first in India; (iii) establishment of a corporatized utility for WSS services in 
Jaipur, the first in the state; (iv) transfer of water supply operations from the state to five municipal 
bodies with adequate support systems; (v) establishment of a state urban governance training 
institute to train all urban functionaries and elected representatives; and (vi) preparation of a 
financial  sustainability  road  map  for  the  sector,  which  includes  a  government  order  to 
automatically adjust the WSS tariff annually.10 The Swachh Bharat Mission (Clean India) has also 
succeeded in ensuring that all households have a toilet. The next stage for improving sanitation

7.  Lessons. The project incorporates lessons from ADB-financed projects in Rajasthan and 
across Asia, such as (i) contract and project implementation periods should be aligned with the 
scale  and  nature  of  works,  their  geographic  spread,  and  capacity  of  project  implementing 
agencies; (ii) early government commitment should be secured to increase staffing in ULBs 
responsible for O&M; (iii) adequate support to build operational and financial capacity of ULBs 
should be linked with infrastructure investments; (iv) private sector engagement should ensure 
professional O&M systems are immediately in place while transferring skills to ULBs;11 (v) gender 
equality and social inclusion (GESI) targets should be based on verified baselines; (vi) an 
integrated  approach  to  sanitation  should  be  pursued  that  combines  centralized  sewerage  
systems provided in more  densely populated areas and decentralized on-site fecal sludge 
management solutions in less populated areas (it is more cost-effective, wider-reaching, and less 
water-dependent than sewerage);12 and (vii) all contracts should include household connections 
in sewered areas to ensure immediate and adequate flows to sewage treatment plants (STPs). 
 
8.  Project modality. The project meets the sector loan modality criteria, as (i) GOR has a 
sector  development  plan;  (ii)  institutional  capacity  is  sufficient  to  implement  the  sector 
development  plan—the  executing  agency  has  significant  experience  in  planning  and 
implementing large-scale projects and reforms, and further support will be provided under the 
project; and (iii) supporting policies are in place, and will be further strengthened through the 
project. The choice of the sector loan modality is justified because the project supports a slice of 
the GOR’s investment program and the criteria for sector loan modality are met. 
 
9.  Alignment with ADB and country priorities. The project is aligned with pillars 2 and 3 
of the country partnership strategy for India, 2018–2022, and mitigation of negative climate 
change impacts.13  It is aligned with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs);14 and ADB 
Strategy  2030,15 particularly  the  operational  priorities  of  (i)  making  cities  more  livable;  (ii) 
strengthening governance and institutional capacity; (iii) accelerating progress in gender equality; 
(iv)  tackling  climate  change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing 
environmental sustainability; and (v) addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequality.

disease (COVID-19) a public health emergency of international concern on 30 January 2020 and 
declared a pandemic on 11 March 2020. 16 The project remains highly relevant in COVID-19 
pandemic context as the provision of safe WSS in homes, schools, marketplaces, and health care 
facilities, and improved hygienic conditions are essential to protecting human health during all 
infectious disease outbreaks, including COVID-19 pandemic.17 The pandemic has led to loss of

B.  Project Description 
 
11.  The project seeks to improve WSS services in secondary towns, including heritage 
towns18  through a sector loan modality. Subprojects with high readiness are prioritized by GOR 
and must meet all the agreed subproject selection criteria.19 The differentiated approach for 
secondary towns in Rajasthan includes a stronger emphasis on ensuring ownership, capacity, 
and readiness of ULBs to take over assets from the state government; and citywide sanitation 
solutions that are more inclusive, cost-effective, and sustainable. The project includes towns with 
a high proportion of indigenous peoples, with three towns (Abu Road, Banswara, and Pratapgarh) 
located in scheduled areas.20 
 
12.  The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) access to potable, affordable, reliable, 
equitable, and environmentally sustainable drinking water supply in all urban areas of Rajasthan 
improved;21 and (ii) health status of urban population, especially the poor and underprivileged, 
improved. 22  The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  quality,  reliability,  equity,  and 
sustainability of WSS services in project towns of Rajasthan improved.23 The investments in WSS 
with 10-year O&M contracts, coupled with institutional strengthening of RUDSICO and ULBs in 
district  headquarters,  heritage  towns,  and  other  market  centers  are  expected  to  ensure 
operational sustainability and improve quality of life in project towns, including for the poor and 
vulnerable. The project is also expected to build resilience of communities to manage health 
pandemics.  There are three project outputs. 
 
13.  Output 1: Water supply system in at least eight project towns improved. By 2027, at 
least eight project towns with about 100,000 households will have five new or rehabilitated water 
treatment plants (WTPs) and 1,350 kilometer (km) distribution networks to provide safer, more 
reliable, and more equitable water supply services. The systems are designed for and are 
expected to provide a 24-hour supply at most times, except during prolonged dry spells (efforts 
by GOR to augment its water supply are ongoing). Water safety plans will be implemented to 
ensure water quality remains potable even during periods of intermittent supply. Distribution 
networks use a district metered area approach, which allows the network to be hydraulically 
isolated; this will help in identifying and resolving water losses, meeting nonrevenue water (NRW) 
targets, and managing water pressure to ensure equitable distribution. All households will have a 
water meter that allows for volumetric billing. The water supply improvements are expected to 
benefit all residents, including the urban poor, by reducing time spent collecting water from other 
sources, which may be costly or unhygienic, while the reduction in waterborne diseases will 
minimize earning losses from missed work due to health issue.

14.  Output 2: Sanitation system in at least 13 project towns developed or improved. By 
2027, at least 13 towns with about 103,000 households will have 19 sewage and one fecal sludge 
treatment plants, 1,300 km sewer networks, and desludging trucks for citywide inclusive sanitation 
through a combination of onsite and sewerage solutions; this will ensure that the benefits—which 
include improved services, a cleaner and more hygienic environment, and better health—are 
shared by all residents, including the urban poor. The approach is cost-effective as it (i) limits 
sewers  to  core  areas,  with  outer  areas  served  through  organized  desludging,  and  safe 
transportation and treatment of sludge; and (ii) prioritizes rehabilitating STPs to meet current 
effluent standards over constructing new assets. Household sewer connections are included, 
including for poor households living in sewered zones. As a climate adaptation measure, project 
consultants will provide support to ULBs in at least five project areas to identify users and structure 
agreements for wastewater reuse. 
 
15.  Output 3: Institutional and human capacities strengthened for sustainable service 
delivery,  gender  equality,  and  improved  public  health.  By  2027,  the  project  will  have 
strengthened the capacity and ensured the readiness of project ULBs to manage water supply 
and/or sanitation services and recover O&M costs. The project will strengthen the contract 
management skills of at least 500 staff and 500 elected council members  of 14 project ULBs to 
support monitoring of contractor performance and service levels, construct or improve office 
space for new WSS divisions, and develop standard procedures for ULB O&M. A data platform 
that incorporates supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA), and a geographic information 
system will be established in each of the 14 project ULBs to support decision-making and efficient 
service delivery. The project includes capacity strengthening of RUDSICO by making its financial 
management system certified by an accredited institution. To promote gender equity, the project 
includes an internship program in RUDSICO so that at least 500 college-age women will gain 
professional experience in a technical field, with the broader objective of increasing the number 
of  women  working  on  urban  development  in  Rajasthan.24 Awareness  programs  on  water 
conservation,  O&M,  financial  sustainability,  climate  change  impacts,  GESI  action  plan 
implementation, and public health (including hygiene and minimizing the spread of communicable 
diseases) will target students, elected officials, and ULB staff, and will be delivered throughout 
the project implementation period. Training will be provided to at least 100 women including 50 
women from scheduled caste, other backward castes, or scheduled tribes with limited economic 
opportunities to build their skills in related areas, such as plumbing and meter reading. 
 
16.  The project will reduce or avoid greenhouse gas emissions by using energy-efficient 
motors, maximizing the  use  of  surface  water sources  to  avoid  pumping  groundwater,  and 
installing solar panels on all facilities that are constructed. Climate adaptation measures of the 
project include rainwater harvesting structures in new RUDSICO buildings. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
17.  Partnership with ADB helps ensure a longer-term policy dialogue on deepening financial 
sustainability  and  institutional  strengthening  reforms,  particularly  in  local  governments,  and 
introduces new good practices. Specifically, ADB will help ensure that the project incorporates 
practical  lessons  and  innovations;  is  inclusive,  resilient,  and  sustainable;  and  introduces 
appropriate technologies, such as a geographic information system, and supervisory control and 
data acquisition with a control and command center. ADB supports sustainability through (i) 
technical due diligence that includes analysis of life-cycle costs, benefit maximization, and climate 
resilience; (ii) requirements for financial sustainability plans; and (iii) support for institutional

B.  Economic and Financial Viability29 
 
26.  Economic analysis. The economic rationale for the government’s intervention is sound, 
as the project aims to provide better quality and more sustainable WSS services in the project 
towns. The economic analysis evaluated the economic feasibility of five sample subprojects in 
three project ULBs.30 The estimated economic internal rates of return ranged from 10.0% to 
22.1%, which exceeds the economic opportunity cost of capital (estimated at 9.0%), indicating 
significant economic returns. The overall sensitivity analysis results are satisfactory, except for                 
(i) the combined worst-case scenario for all sanitation subprojects in three ULBs, and (ii) the 
scenario combining a capital cost overrun of 20% and a decrease in benefits of 20% for the 
sanitation subproject in Kuchaman. However, the economic viability of the sample subprojects is 
expected to increase if unquantifiable benefits such as environmental improvements are included 
in the analysis. 
 
27.  Financial analysis. An incremental recurrent cost analysis was conducted for five sample 
subprojects in three project towns (footnote 31). None of the sample subprojects will generate 
adequate revenue for full O&M cost recovery through the existing tariff. This was confirmed by a 
cash-flow analysis of project ULBs conducted to assess their capacity to cover incremental 
recurrent  costs  from  all  revenues,  such  as  tax  income,  user  charges,  and  external  grant 
resources. To ensure subproject sustainability, the GOR approved the financial sustainability 
plans prepared by the project ULBs, which include measures such as  (i) periodic tariff increase, 
(ii) introduction of a volumetric tariff, (iii) improvement of collection efficiency, and (iv) GOR’s 
financial support to fill gaps.  
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
28.  The project has a sound institutional setup. PIUs are housed within each project ULB to 
ensure ULBs are closely involved. The project will construct or improve the physical PIU office in 
each ULB, and GOR has agreed to increase the number of technical staff in each project ULB 
(ULBs are responsible for O&M, including supervision of the O&M to be undertaken by works 
contractors for 10 years). The Centre for Urban Development and Governance established by 
GOR will continue capacity development through ongoing training for urban functionaries and 
elected  representatives.  Nevertheless,  risk  to  project  sustainability  is  high,  because  all 
subprojects are unlikely to generate adequate revenue for full O&M cost recovery through tariffs 
alone without regular tariff revisions. To mitigate this risk, GOR has agreed to reinstate and 
implement its policy for periodic adjustment of the water tariff, provide transfers to ULBs to fill 
funding gaps, and strengthen collection of the urban development tax. The project will also finance 
the initial O&M by using private contractors to support ULBs during the transition period. As a 
project requirement, GOR and ULBs have approved financial sustainability plans that will be  
monitored by GOR and ADB during implementation through quarterly progress reports.31 For 
environmental sustainability, the project will improve environmental health with discharge of 
treated wastewater and ensure more optimal use of water resources through improved water 
management and wastewater reuse.

D.  Governance 
 
29.  The assessment of state-owned enterprise governance concluded that RUDSICO has 
been complying with the standard procedures and processes of the Companies Act 2013 and 
directives of the Ministry of Corporate Affairs. Areas of strength include the overall governance 
framework and significant experience of the merged entities to manage and execute large-scale 
internally and externally aided projects. However, RUDSICO was only recently established, and 
both RUDSICO and GOR need to show sustained commitment to achieving greater operational 
synergies  between  all  merged  entities.  Institutional  reform  enables  the  improvement  of 
RUDSICO’s viability as it can implement government- and donor-sponsored projects, and also 
lend funds to ULBs and others for urban development projects. Yet, it takes time for RUDISCO to 
be fully equipped with staff and fully function. During this transition period, consultancy services 
under the project will strengthen corporate governance practices in RUDSICO, with a focus on 
financial management and human resources, and strengthen technical support for ULBs.32 
Integrity due diligence for RUDSICO has been conducted and no significant integrity risks have 
been identified. 
 
30.  Financial management. A financial management assessment was conducted for the 
LSGD and RUDSICO in accordance with ADB’s guidelines.33 The LSGD and RUDSICO have 
adequate financial management capacity to (i) record financial transactions, (ii) provide reliable 
and timely financial reports, and (iii) safeguard the financial assets. The financial management 
risk at RUDSICO is assessed to be substantial mainly because of (i) decentralized fund flow to 
several PIUs, (ii) inexperienced financial staff, and (iii) delays in approval of RUDSICO’s audited 
financial statements. The main risk-mitigation actions are (i) appointing qualified financial staff, 
including an external consultant; (ii) providing training on ADB’s financial management and 
disbursement procedures; (iii) requiring quarterly financial reporting; (iv) ensuring the project is 
audited by RUDSICO’s internal audit function; (v) using the agreed audit terms of reference and 
reporting templates; and (vi) adhering to statutory entity audit timelines. The project financial 
statements will be audited annually by an auditor acceptable to ADB, following auditing standards 
acceptable to ADB. 
 
31.  Procurement. All procurement of goods and works and consultant recruitment will adhere 
to the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time), and the Procurement 
Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). Hybrid contracts with 
design–build for STPs and WTPs, item rates for pipelaying works, and 10-years of O&M service 
were selected as offering the best fit for the project’s objectives. Larger packages were formed to 
attract more experienced contractors capable of providing design, works, and O&M services. 
Private sector participation in O&M is important to ensure sustainability of assets after completion 
and for transferring skills to the ULBs. Part of the contractor’s payment during the O&M phase is 
linked to performance targets. The strategic integration of all these key aspects in the contracts 
contributes to achieving value for money.

The project will support the Government of Rajasthan (GOR) in expanding access to improved water supply services for about 570,000 people, and improved sanitation services for about 720,000 people in at least 14 secondary towns1 by drawing on experiences and lessons from three earlier projects funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Rajasthan.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated September 2020 is provided for the ADB project 42267-031 in India.
